DataElement.preferredName: Intravenous Route of Administration Contrast Agent Administered Name
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The name of the intravenous contrast agent administered during the imaging procedure.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Procedure Agents Domain Intravenous Route of Administration Contrast Agent Administered
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A domain utilized for the submission of information encompassing and representing data, vocabulary or records related to agents used as part of a procedure._Administration within or into a vein or veins._Substances administered during imaging procedures that allows delineation of internal structures. Contrast agents appear opaque due to the difference in absorption of X-rays or other electromagnetic waves and surrounding tissue._The act of having given something (e.g., a medication or test).

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A domain utilized for the submission of information encompassing and representing data, vocabulary or records related to agents used as part of a procedure.

Concepts.definition: A domain utilized for the submission of information encompassing and representing data, vocabulary or records related to agents used as part of a procedure.

Property.preferredName: Intravenous Route of Administration Contrast Agent Administered
Property.preferredDefinition: Administration within or into a vein or veins.:Substances administered during imaging procedures that allows delineation of internal structures. Contrast agents appear opaque due to the difference in absorption of X-rays or other electromagnetic waves and surrounding tissue.:The act of having given something (e.g., a medication or test).

Concepts.definition: Administration of a drug within or into a vein or veins. Introduction of the drug directly into venous circulation results in 100% bioavailability due to an absence of the absorption phase, provides a precise and continuous mode of drug therapy, especially for drugs with a narrow therapeutic index.

Substances administered during imaging procedures that allows delineation of internal structures. Contrast agents appear opaque due to the difference in absorption of X-rays or other electromagnetic waves and surrounding tissue.
The act of having given something (e.g., a medication or test).
